loans.use: For the purchase of seeds and fertilizers to benefit their harvest and quality of their products.

loans.name: María

texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Eugenia Ruiz is 21-years-old she lives with the father of her two children, Cristian Roman. Together they are a small hardworking family.

Maria owns a small grocery store and Cristian is a construction worker. Maria has asked for a loan to purchase merchandise such as noodles, flour, bread, tomatoes, potatoes and meat. With the money they generate from the store they hope to expand their business.

As of right now, Maria lives with her parents. Her dream is to earn enough money from her store to buy her own house.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise such as noodles, flour, bread, tomatoes, potatoes and meat.

loans.name: Myrian

texts.en:
Myrian P. is 38 years old, and married with five children. Her oldest child is now out of school and works as a domestic servant. She helps the family with household expenses.

Myrian works in horticulture. She grows tomatoes, carrots and lettuce. She learned this trade from her parents who were also farmers.

With dedication, Myrian and her family have been able to move forward. Over the years they have built their own house and she has been able to pay for the education of her children.

Myrian has asked for a loan to buy cloth to be used to protect her crops from the extreme summer sun in Paraguay. In the future she also wishes to buy a horse and cart with which to distribute her vegetables.

loans.use: To buy cloth to be used to protect her crops from the sun

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosalia is a 41-year-old single mother of three. All of her children are still in primary school. She is dedicated to farming and the sale of her crops. She learned this business from her parents who were also farmers. When she was a girl she helped her parents sell their crops in the streets with baskets.

With the money she generates from her crops, Rosalia has been able to build a house as well as invest in the education of her children. She has asked for a loan to buy seeds. She will expand her products by planting more fruit for the summer months. In the future she hopes to buy more land and expand her farm.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Martha Aqueda

texts.es:
Martha E. is married and her business consists of making natural juices and selling them in the central market in Leon. Before starting this business she sold desserts from home and her clients then asked her to sell juices and natural squashes, and her and her husband managed to raise $15 to start their new business.

They have now been doing this for 6 years. Although they don't have a stall in the market they have a tricycle which they use to transport their products, and the good thing is that they make everything fresh and the more they invest the more money they earn.

During the three years that she has been getting loans from CEPRODEL she has been able to invest in her business and it is the only income her family has.

Martha's aim is to keep saving so that she can get her own stall in the market and strengthen her business, God permitting, so that they can finish building themselves a nice house.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Martha E. es casada, su negocio consiste en preparar jugos naturales y venderlos en todo el mercado Central de León. Antes de comenzar con este negocio vendía repostería(postres) a domicilio y sus clientes le pidieron que tambien vendiera frescos (o Jugos naturales), de manera que con su esposo lograron recaudar $15 dólares para iniciar con este nuevo negocio.

Ahora lleva 6 años desempeñando esta actividad. Aun no tienen un módulo dentro del mercado, le toca transportarse en un triciclo para ofrecer su producto, lo bueno es que ella ofrece algo que se consume a diario y mientras mas invierte en el negocio sus ganancias van aumentando.

En estos tres años que lleva de trabajar con el crédito de CEPRODEL, ha sabido aprovecharlos y los invierte bien en el negocio, pues es su único medio de ingreso para mantener a su familia.

La meta de doña Martha es ir ahorrando todas sus ganancias para poder comprar su propio módulo en el mercado y fortalecer su negocio...y si Dios le permite...terminar de construir su casita para tener una vivienda Digna.

loans.use: To buy utensils to make squash and ingredients: sugar, rice, fruits etc/Compra de Activos Fijos, utencilios para hacer sus refrescos, asi como los insumos: Azucar, Arroz, Frutas ...etc.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en: Farida A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in south western Azerbaijan. She is 48 years old, married and has three children. She sells fruits and vegetables in the Beylagan city market. Farida has ten years experience at this business. She wants to buy more varieties of goods. Farida needs a $700 loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Victoriano

texts.en:
Mr. Victoriano P. is 49-years-old and married to Candida Adomo with whom he has three children. Their children are ages 8, 10 and 14 respectively. All of them currently go to the local school.

Victoriano is a refrigerator repairman. He has studied to work in this field since he as young. Before starting his own business, he worked for a company that sells refrigerators and freezers for many years. After having acquired sufficient experience, Victoriano, decided to leave his job at this company and work independently. At this time he opened his current repair shop. It has now been 20 years since its opening and the shop is still doing well. He provides for his humble family and through his hard work has overcome many obstacles in his life. He is very proud that he has been able to rise above these inconveniences.

In the future he hopes to improve the infrastructure of his shop and expand his business to sell household appliances in addition to repair. He has asked for a loan to buy parts for refrigerators and air conditioners.

loans.use: To buy replacement parts

loans.name: Maritza Del Carmen

texts.es:
Maritza is a mom who has worked very hard over the past years to make sure that her family is well taken care of. She was a stay-at-home mom for the past 7 years, but due to economic reasons since her husband was the only one working, she decided to start her own business to be able to provide for her family.

This is how she started her own business at the local market in the city of Managua. She started by selling a few things out of a mobile cart. She had little money, but due to her faith and dedication to help her family move ahead have made it easier for her in getting to where she is now.

CEPRODEL offered a friendly hand during the most difficult times Maritza had to face. Their financial support helped her rent a small space and purchase more material which means more merchandise and more profit. She has had 6 loans which all have been paid for.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

Maritza es madre de familia, razon que la ha llevado a luchar por el bienestar de su hijo, su esposo y el de ella misma. Hace mas de 7 años se dedicaba unicamente a los quehaceres del hogar, sin embargo ante la realidad economica que vivia (solo el esposo laboraba), ella tuvo que decidirse y montar su propio negocio para poder sustentar su nucleo familiar.

Es de esta manera como nace su negocio en el mercado mayoreo de la ciudad de managua apenas vendiendo pocas cosas en un carreton. Su capital era poco pero su fe y su dedicacion por satisfacer las necesidades de su familia, la llevaron hasta donde esta el dia de hoy.

CEPRODEL fue una mano amiga en los momentos dificiles de Maritza, ya que le brindo el financiamiento necesario para adquisicion y mejoramiento de local asi como el incremento de materiales lo que se traduce en mas productos y mayores ventas. Su record ed de 6 creditos con una buena calificacion.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is 37 years old, is married and has 2 children. She owns a grocery store, where she sells products needed to make "chipas" (which are a typical meal of Paraguay) like flour, cheese, eggs, oil, etc.

The products needed to produce chipas make for good sales because Carmen's business is located in an area where chipas are predominantly produced. Her workday begins very early in the morning, with the purchase of these raw materials from their suppliers. These suppliers are in the city Eusebio Ayala (Barrero Large).

Carmen says that this business of selling products for the development of chipas required financial capital and without the loans given to her by the Paraguayan Foundation, she wouldn't have been successful. To be successful in this business, one must have sufficient inventory of the necessary products because the prices constantly change, hence the profitability constantly changes, which affects the small producers.

She is asking for a loan to buy more goods for sale in her grocery, such as soda, beer, sugar, meat, milk, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Carmen tiene 37 años está casada y tiene 2 hijos, ella es propietaria de una despensa y también vende productos para elaborar chipas como almidón, queso, huevo, aceite, etc.

Las materias primas para elaborar chipas (la chipa es una comida típica de Paraguay) tienen buen movimiento de ventas ya que su negocio se encuentra en una zona eminentemente productora de chipas y su jornada laboral se inicia a muy temprana horas de la mañana con la compra de éstas materias primas de sus proveedores que principalmente se encuentran en la ciudad de Eusebio Ayala (Barrero Grande).

Carmen comenta que en éste negocio de vender productos para la elaboración de chipas se requiere de capital y gracias a los préstamos que le otorgó la Fundación Paraguaya pudo hacerse de capital ya que de lo contrario el negocio no será rentable porque uno debe contar con stock suficiente de éstos productos ya que el constante cambio de los precios que se sucede en el mercado hace que juegue directamente con los costos y por ende la rentabilidad y principalmente éstos cambios de precio afectan a los pequeños productores es de ahí la importancia de contar con un capital de trabajo.

Ella solicita un crédito para poder comprar más mercaderías para vender en su despensa, tales como gaseosa, cerveza, azúcar, carne, leche, etc.

loans.use: To purchase products like:  sodas, beer, sugar, meats, milk, etc. (Para la compra de gaseosa, cerveza, azúcar, carne, leche, etc.)

loans.name: Rafig

texts.en: Rafig O. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 45 years old. Rafig owns a small car service store. Rafig has ten years experience at this business. He wants to buy new equipment and expand his business, therefore he needs a $600 loan. This is his first loan.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.es:
Eugenio is 53 years old and married with 4 children. He is the owner of a business that sells bags made of polyethylene. He has been involved in this business for more than 20 years, which has allowed him to build his own house, support his entire family, and educate his children. Currently, he has a good number of customers and clients to whom he sells and supplies his products in the regions of San Bernardino, Altos, Ypacaraí, Pirayú, Caacupé, and Tobatí. He transports his products by means of motorcycle as the majority of his customers are stores, mini-markets, etc.

Currently, he is working on opening a store in the city of Ypacaraí to market his products or independently sell them door-to-door to homes, which will possibly increase his sales. One of Eugenio's worries is that he cannot provide opportunities for young people, which is why even his daughters left for Spain in search of work since there are no available jobs in his country. He seeks a loan to buy more bags.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Eugenio tiene 53 años está casado y tiene 4 hijos, el es propietario de un negocio que se dedica a vender bolsas de polietileno, en ésta actividad está hace más de 20 años, manifiesta que gracias a éste trabajo pudo hacerse de casa propia, mantener a toda su familia e inclusive educar a sus hijos. Actualmente posee buena cantidad de clientela a quienes provee de estas mercaderías y las mismas son de la zona de San Bernardino, Altos, Ypacaraí, Pirayú, Caacupé, Tobatí. La distribución de sus mercaderías lo realiza en su motocicleta y sus clientelas en su mayorías son las despensas, minimercados, copetines, etc.

Actualmente tiene proyectado abrir un local en la ciudad de Ypacaraí dónde pueda ofrecer y vender éstos productos e independientemente a las ventas a domicilio que lo realiza, esto le permitirá tener una mayor posibilidad de vender más. Una de las preocupaciones del señor Eugenio es la falta de oportunidad laboral muy en especial para los jóvenes ya que por esa razón una de sus hijas tuvo que viajar a España en busca de un trabajo ya que aquí en nuestro país no lo encontró. Solicita el crédito para la compra de bolsas de polietileno.

loans.use: to buy polyethylene bags of different colors and sizes

loans.name: Govher

texts.en: Govher M. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 45 years old, married and has three children. She sells fruits and vegetables in the Beylagan city bazaar. She started her business ten years ago. She wants a $1000 loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Ruth Maria

texts.es:
Ruth Maria has been selling kids', men's and women's clothing such as shirts, trousers, shorts, socks and towels etc for 14 years. She started by investing her savings of many years of $2,000, and with this she started to travel to the capital (Managua) to buy merchandise in bulk.

She started as a wandering merchant, walking through the streets of Leon with a suitcase full of clothes, through the markets looking for clients. She had a huge desire to overcome her circumstances and decided to receive credit so that she could establish her business, and she rented a stall in Leon's central market.

Ruth has received 5 loans and has now been working with our organization for 14 months, and her testimony follows:

"Thanks to the great advice about managing my loans I have been able to move forward. My husband has not found a job so it is up to me to support our family and I do all I can so that my son can have a good education - he is the youngest but I hope he will overcome and become a professional. Each loan that I have received I have invested in increasing my merchandise with seasonal clothing."

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Ruth María tiene 14 años desempeñando este trabajo, vende ropa interior para niños, damas y caballeros, blusas, pantalones, camisas, short, calcetines, toallas...etc. Inició invirtiendo sus ahorros de muchos años U$2,000 (dos mil dolares), con esto ella comenzó a viajar a la capital(Managua) para coprar la mercaderia al por mayor.

Ella al inicio como comerciante ambulante, caminaba con la maleta de ropa por toda la ciudad de León y los mercados buscando clientela, pero con los buenos deseos de superarse decidió adquirir los créditos para poder establecer su negocio, alquilando un módulo en el mercado Central de León.

Doña Ruth ha recibido 5 créditos y actualmente está cumpliendo 14 meses de trabajar con nuestra organización, su testimonio es el siguiente:

"Gracias a los buenos consejos para saber administrar mi crédito he logrado salir adelante, mi esposo no ha encontrado trabajo, así que por el momento es a mi a quien me toca mantener a la familia y hago todo mi esfuerzo para que mi hijito logre tener una buena educación, el es menor de edad pero deseo que se supere y sea un buen profesional. Cada crédito que recibo lo invierto en la compra de mercadería para surtir el negocio con ropa de la temporada".

loans.use: To buy merchandise (Children's, women's and men's clothes) / Compra de Mercadería (Ropa para niños, damas y caballeros)

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo is 44 years old, and is married with two children. He owns a grocery store where he sells a wide variety of basic necessities. He also has cows which produce milk for him to sell, as well as to make cheese.

He has had the grocery store business for over five years. His increased sales benefit from the fact that his store is located in the center of the city of Arroyos y Esteros, which is a high traffic area every day.

His business is well-supplied, thanks to the loans granted by Fundación Paraguaya. These funds allowed him to purchase merchandise of all types but particularly items in daily demand such as meats, sugar, oil, beverages, eggs, noodles, etc.

Gerardo declares that he needs to purchase a three-door refrigerator to keep his beverages cold given that he does a good sales volume over the weekends. This is particularly true now, during the summer, a time when cool drinks are in particularly high demand.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Gerardo Tiene 44 años está casado y tiene 2 hijos, el es propietario de una despensa donde vende todo tipo de insumos de primera necesidad; también tiene vacas de las cuales vende la leche en su propio negocio además de elaborar queso.

El negocio de la despensa lo tiene hace más de 5 años y registra buena venta ya que está ubicado en el centro mismo de la ciudad de Arroyos y Esteros, dónde hay buena concurrencia de gente todos los días.

Su negocio está muy bien surtido, gracias a los préstamos que le otorgó la Fundación Paraguaya pudo comprar mercaderías de todas las variedades y muy especialmente los productos de rotación diaria como ser, carne, azúcar, aceite, bebidas de todas las marcas, huevo, fideo, etc.

Gerardo, afirma que necesita comprar un congelador de 3 puertas para mantener bien frías sus bebidas ya que los fines de semana registra buena venta y en ésta época de calor las bebidas son los de mayor venta.

loans.use: Purchase a three-door refrigerator/freezer.

loans.name: Kamran

texts.en: Kamran N. is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fuzuli region of Azerbaijan. Now he is settled with his wife and three children in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. Kamran is 36 years old. He sells women's clothes in the Beylagan city bazaar. He started his business ten years ago. He wants a $1200 loan to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Melba Rosa

texts.es:
Melba Rosa has a large family with 4 children. With a lot of effort and dedication she has succeeded in moving the family ahead. Three of her children are secondary school students and the oldest is now preparing for a professional career.

This business started in the city's wholesale market approximately 8 years ago, with 106 USD loaned by a relative. Her determination to prosper has brought growth to her business. Although when she started the business she had only two large baskets with cosmetics, she now has succeeded in buying her stall and making improvements, thanks to the financing she has received from CEPRODEL.

Melba Rosa has continued to replace the inventory she's sold while incorporating new products, which has attracted more clients and increased her earnings. She has been a CEPRODEL client for 3 years with a history of 6 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Melba Rosa tiene una amplia familia que consta de cuatro hijos; con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación ha logrado impulsarlos hacia adelante, tres de ellos son estudiantes de secundaria y el mayor ya se esta formando en una carrera profesional.

El negocio nace en las instalaciones del mercado mayoreo de la ciudad de managua hace aproximadamente 8 años, con un capital de US$106.00, mismo que los consiguio prestados por un familiar. Su lucha por prosperar la ha llevado a crecer, pues cuando inicio solo tenia dos canastos con cosmeticos , sin embargo hoy en dia y gracias al financiamiento de CEPRODEL logro comprar su tramo y le ha hecho mejoras.

Asi mismo, ha retroalimentado su inventario y a la vez ha logrado incorporar en el mismo nuevos productos, atrayendo asi mayor clientela y logrando mas ganacias. Ella es cliente de CEPRODEL desde hace 3 años con un record de 6 creditos

loans.use: Purchase of inventory

loans.name: Ruslan

texts.en: Ruslan V. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 45 years old, married and has three children. Ruslan is a taxi driver. He has started this business four years ago. He wants to borrow a $800 loan and expand his business.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Maria Antonieta

texts.es:
Maria is a hard-working woman that works most of the day as secretary in a company which is open from 9:00 am. to 5:00 pm. Mondays through Wednesdays, and then apart from this work, sells fine jewelry to customers from pictures and catalogues. In order to comply with her customers' orders, she travels bi-weekly to the city of Lima (where she purchases her jewelry items for sale). During her travels, this selfless mother still manages to take care of her home and her family, as well as care for her very elderly mother and her needs. This is the reason she is asking for your help in order to grow her inventory and meet the requests of her clients, with the hope of increasing her income and standard of living. Do not be indifferent to Maria's needs, and let us work with her to help her continue to care for her own mother who requires greater care and treatment.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

María, es una dama muy trabajadora que ocupa el mayor tiempo del día a su labor de secretaria en un grifo en el que trabaja desde las 9:00 am. hasta las 5:00 pm. de lunes a miércoles y muy aparte a esta labor vende prendas de vestir a las personas que realizan los pedidos de sus ofertas por medio de fotos y/o catálogos.Ella trae su mercadería de la ciudad de Lima para poder cumplir con sus pedidos, razón por la cual viaja quincenalmente a la capital para realizar sus compras. Durante sus viajes su abnegada madre cuida su hogar y por ser su único familiar, María vela también por el bienestar de su madre quién es ya de gran avanzada edad.A raíz de este hecho pide le ayudemos a conseguir la cantidad que necesita para aumentar su mercadería a fin de satisfacer los pedidos de las personas con el objetivo de incrementar sus ingresos económicos y nivel de vida familiar.No seamos indiferentes ante la necesidad de Maria y colaboremos con ella y su anciana madre quién requiere de mayores cuidados y tratamientos

loans.use: To consolidate the second occupation of this incredible and selfless mother and daughter. (Inyección de capital para consolidar la segunda ocupación de esta increíble y abnegada madre e hija.)

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es:
Gloria Maria is a loving mother and dedicated wife. Her life revolves around her family. She is also a business owner. She has 5 sons. Together with her husband they've made sure that their sons are well-provided. Four of them are college educated.

About 1 1/2 year ago, Gloria had to make a choice between staying at home and working at the local market in the city of Managua. She started with $1,000 usd which 1/2 was from savings and the other half was from a loan.

Her business locale is now very spacious and in better conditions. For the past 8 months, CEPRODEL has been part of this success story in the life of Gloria Maria.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

Gloria Maria es ama de casa, madre incondicional y esposa dedicada. Su vida gira en torno del bienestar de su familia, sin embargo ella tambien es propietaria y trabajadora de su negocio. Su familia esta conformada por cinco hijos fruto de su matrimonio a los que en conjunto con su esposo han tratado de sacar adelante. Cuatro de ellos son becados universitarios.

Hace 1½ año Gloria tuvo que abandonar la vida únicamente de ama de casa e iniciar su negocio en el mercado Mayoreo en la ciudad de managua, el cual inicio con un capital de U$1,000.00 los cuales eran una parte ahorro y la otra parte prestamo. El local cuando inicio solo constaba de madera y zinc.

Actualmente su negocio es amplio y las condiciones del mismo son muy buenas. CEPRODEL ha sido parte de este avance en la vida de Gloria Maria durante 8 meses.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Arlen Carolina

texts.es:
This young entrepreneur, head of a family, with a strong desire to get ahead, has set up her own business in the wholesale market. From the age of twelve, this young woman was working as a street vendor selling coffee and bread. As the years went by, the income she earned as a street vendor was no longer sufficient to cover her needs. The idea of starting her own business was born from that recognition.

Four years ago, Arlen started this business with 213 USD in capital, money that she had saved during a long time, with a lot of sacrifice. With her sales and effort she has succeeded in buying the stall where she runs her business and making improvements to it.

CEPRODEL has been working with Arlen for 3 years; she has received 16 loans. As an institution CEPRODEL believes that it is extremely important to support enterprising young people like Arlen, since their initiatives generally wind up creating jobs.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Esta joven emprendedora, Jefa de familia y con grandes deseos de superación ha colocado su negocio propio en el mercado mayoreo. Desde los doce años esta joven ha trabajado de vendedora ambulante vendiendo cafe y pan, sin embargo al pasar de los años estos ingresos no fueron suficientes para cubrir sus necesidades, de ahi nace la idea de colocar su negocio.

Desde hace 4 años empieza este negocio con un capital de US$213.00 mismos que ahorró durante mucho tiempo y con sacrificio. Con sus ventas y esfuerzo logra comprar el tramo y acondicionarlo.

CEPRODEL trabaja con Arlen desde hace 3 años y su record es de 16 prestamos. Como institucion CEPRODEL cree de suma importancia apoyar este tipo de jóvenes emprendedores, cuyas iniciativas generalmente se vuelven generadoras de empleo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Guillermina Patricia

texts.es:
Guillermina Patricia currently runs a small stall inside the central market in León where she sells popular household products and foods that are staples in Nicaragua such as rice, oil, beans, etc. She acquires these products through distributors who sell wholesale.

She is married and with her husband she tends to this business in which she has worked for more than 13 years. When she was left unemployed, she looked for an alternative way to earn her income, and began selling clothing and beauty items such as rings, earrings and hair accessories in the street. She started her business with 33 USD.

Guillermina has been working for two years with the loans extended by CEPRODEL. The 8 loans she has received have helped her stock her business, rent a stall in the market and add variety to her inventory in order to offer her clients a little bit of everything. Her goal is to buy her stall in the market in order to free herself from the expense of rent and improve the structure of the stall.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Guillermina Patricia actualmente tiene un pequeño módulo dentro del mercado Central en León donde vende productos populares para el hogar y productos de la canasta básica de los Nicaragüenses como el Arroz, Azucar, Aceite, Frijoles etc. Estos productos los obtienes por medio de Distribuidores que venden al por mayor (a precios accesibles).

Ella esta casada y junto con su esposo atienden el negocio que lleva mas de 13 años de trabajar en él. Al quedarse desempleada buscó otra alternativa, inició vendiendo ropa en la calle, articulos de belleza como anillos, aretes, y adornos para el cabello. Inició con U$33(treinta y tres dolares)

Lleva dos años trabajando con los créditos que otorga la organización (CEPRODEL), y los 8 créditos que ha tenido le ayudaron a surtir el negocio, alquilar un módulo del Mercado y variar su mercadería para ofrecer a sus clientes de todo un poco. Tiene como meta comprar su modulo para no seguir alquilando y mejorar la infraestructura.

loans.use: Buy food staples (rice, beans, sugar, oil) and other products to sell to her clients

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
Mrs. Santos is 35-years-old and lives in the town of Canchachugo, in the district of Usquil in La Libertad. She only went to school until third grade, and she has 4 children who still depend on her. She makes a living by selling ponchos, knapsacks, hats, corn starch, and ice cream at the different festivals in the communities in Sierra de La Libertad, and mainly in a town called Chincimbara in the province of Julcán.

Mrs. Santos joined the Canchachugo Communal Bank through an aunt and obtained her first loan of 300 nuevos soles ($100), with which she purchased an ice cream machine. The recent loan from Manuela Ramos of 1,800 nuevos soles ($598) will be paid back in 4 months and will let her buy hats, for which she needs a large sum of money. She will also buy corn to make chuño, a starch extracted from corn.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Santos tiene 35 años de edad, vive en el caserío de Canchachugo, Distrito de Usquil departamento de La Libertad. Estudió solo hasta el tercer año de primaria; tiene 4 hijos que aun dependen de ella. La señora se dedica a la venta de ponchos, alforjas, sombreros, hasta chuño de maíz y helados en las diferentes ferias de las comunidades de la Sierra de La Libertad y principalmente en un caserío llamado Chinchimbara provincia de Julcán. La señora Santos ingresó el Banco Comunal “Canchachugo” por una tía y obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300 ($100) con los cuales completó el dinero para la compra de una máquina para preparar helados. El reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.1,800.00 ($598) que cancelará en 4 meses, le sirvió para comprar sombreros, para lo cual se necesita una fuerte cantidad de dinero, además compró maíz para la elaboración de chuño (alimento extraído del maíz).

loans.use: Purchase of hats and the purchase of corn to make starch.

loans.name: Felipa Teonila

texts.es:
Mrs. Felipa Teonila is 56-years-old and lives in the province of Otuzco in La Libertad. She only had three years of schooling. She has 3 children, of whom 2 still depend on her. She is also in charge of her granddaughter, whom she has raised since she was born.

Felipa makes a living by selling bread, honey, and cheeses. She also knows how to weave very well; she makes tablecloths and bedspreads and sells them on Tacna street in the province of Otuzco. She also buys animals like sheep, pigs, and hens, which she fattens and sells.

She is a member of the Communal Bank "Sagrado Corazón of Jesús" (Sacred Heart of Jesus), where she obtained her first loan of 300 nuevos soles, with which she purchased feed for her animals. The recent loan from Manuela Ramos of 1,000 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, will let her buy honey and thread at wholesale prices so she can make better profits when she sells them. Felipa dreams about stopping selling in the street and having her own store where she can have her own bakery.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Felipa Teonila tiene 56 años de edad, vive en la Provincia de Otuzco, Departamento de La Libertad. Ella tuvo solo 3 años de estudios; tiene 3 hijos de los cuales 2 aun dependen de ella y esta a cargo de su nieta que la ha criado desde que nació.

La señora Felipa se dedica a la venta de pan, miel de abeja, quesos y también sabe tejer muy bien; hace tapetes, colchas y los vende en la calle Tacna de la provincia de Otuzco. Además compra animales como: oveja, cerdos, gallinas, los cuales engorda y vende.

Es socia del Banco Comunal “Sagrado Corazón de Jesús” donde obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 ($ 100) con los cuales compró alimento para sus animales. El reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.1,000.00 soles ($ 332) el cual pagará en un plazo de 4 meses, le sirvió para comprar miel de abeja e hilos al por mayor para que así pueda obtener mayor ganancia al venderlos. La señora Felipa sueña con dejar de vender en la calle y tener un local propio así como con tener su propia panadería.

loans.use: Purchase of honey and thread.

loans.name: Brigida

texts.es:
Brigida is single with two children, who are the reason for her daily fight for a better life. She started her business 7 years ago after having worked as a secretary in the general secretaria of the FSLN (Sandinista National Liberation Front, the political party currently in power in Nicaragua).

Brigida has been working with CEPRODEL for about 3 years and has a record of 13 loans. She has undoubtedly put forward a lot of effort for her children and her business. She began the business with $25 in capital selling clothing in the streets until she found a site (a plot of land in the open air) where she set up her business. She has continued to improve the site in order to offer a wider variety of clothing and better security to her clientele.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Brigida es soltera con dos hijos, razon por la que lucha dia a dia. Comienza su negocio hace 7 años despues de haber rabajado como secretaria en la Secretaría del FSLN.

Con CEPRODEL Brigida tiene de trabajar alrededor de 3 años con un record de 13 creditos. Indudablemente se ha esforzado mucho por sus hijos y por llevar hacia adelante su negocio. Ella comenzo con un capital de US$25.00 vendiendo ropa de manera ambulante hasta encontrar un local (terreno al aire libre) donde se posiciono. A la fecha ella ha ido acondicionando el local para asi ofrecer mas variedad de ropa con mayor seguridad para su clientela.

loans.use: Buy used clothing in bulk

loans.name: Lelis Francisca

texts.es:
Mrs. Lelis Francisca is 28-years-old and lives in the province of Otuzco in La Libertad. She only went to school until third grade, and she has one son who still depends on her. Lelis makes a living by selling bread and cheeses and also knows how to weave. She makes tablecloths and bedspreads and sells them on Tacna street in the province of Otuzco.

Previously she didn't have a business; she only tended to the farm and to raising her animals, but thanks to the first loan that Manuela Ramos offered her, she was able to start her business and continued to raise her animals to sell them. She is a new member of the Communal Bank "Sagrado Corazón" (Sacred Heart), and has recently obtained her second credit of 300 nuevos soles ($100), which she will pay back in 4 months. With this amount she purchased candy and bread to sell and used another portion on feed for her animals

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Lelis Francisca tiene 28 años de edad, vive en la provincia de Otuzco departamento de La Libertad. Ella estudió solo hasta el tercer año de primaria; tiene 1 solo hijo el cual aun depende de ella. La señora Lelis se dedica a la venta de pan, quesos y también sabe tejer hace algunos tapetes, colchas y eso los vende en la calle Tacna de la provincia de Otuzco.

Anteriormente no tenía negocio, solo se dedicaba a la chacra y a la crianza de sus animales pero gracias al primer préstamo que le brindo Manuela Ramos pudo poner su negocio y continúo con la crianza de sus animales para venderlos. La señora es una socia nueva en el Banco Comunal “Sagrado Corazón”, recientemente ha obtenido su segundo crédito por S/.300.00 ($100), que será cancelado en 4 meses, con este monto compró dulces y pan para venderlos y otra parte lo empleó en la compra de alimento para sus animales.

loans.use: Purchase of candy and bread.  Purchase of feed for animals.

loans.name: Adela Alicia

texts.es:
Adela is 52 years old and was not able to finish her education. She has a daughter who no longer depends on her, and lives in the Jerusalén section of the district of La Esperanza. Her business is located in the Parque Industrial market, where she sells red meat, chicken and cheese purchased wholesale from persons who bring them from Cajamarca. Before starting her business, she worked as an employee in a sporting goods store. She was able to put aside some savings and later started a small store in her home where she sold meats. Adela banks at the communal bank “Santa Elena II” and receives her first loan of $100USD with which she buys meat, cheese and chicken in greater quantity. With the recent loan of $266USD from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in six months, she bought vegetables at wholesale, meats, cheeses and poultry. Adela would like to have more comfort in her home, and her own store location.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Adela tiene 52 años, su grado de instrucción es de superior incompleta, tiene una sola hija que ya no depende de ella vive en el sector Jerusalén en el distrito de La Esperanza, Provincia de Trujillo, Departamento La Libertad. La Señora Adela tiene su negocio en el Mercado Parque Industrial ubicado en la segunda etapa de Manuel Arévalo, distrito de La Esperanza, ella vende carnes rojas, pollo y quesos que compra al por mayor a personas que traen de Cajamarca. Antes de iniciar su negocio trabajaba como empleada en una tienda de productos deportivos, fue ahorrando y luego puso una pequeña bodeguita en su casa para posteriormente dedicarse a la venta de carnes. La señora Adela ingresa al Banco Comunal “Santa Elena II” y obtiene su primer préstamo de S/300.00 ($100) con los cuales compra carne, quesos y pollo en mayor cantidad. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.800.00 ($ 266) el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, compró menestras al por mayor, carnes, quesos y pollo. La señora Adela es tener mas comodidad en su casa y tener su propio puesto.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables at wholesale.  Purchase meats, cheeses, and poultry.

loans.name: Julia Mercedes

texts.es:
Julia is 38 years old. Her level of education is some high school. She has 4 children, of whom 3 are dependent on her. She is a very dynamic and hard-working woman. She lives in Manuel Arévalo in the district of La Esperanza, the province of Trujillo and the department of La Libertad.

Many years ago, Julia worked selling clothing that she bought wholesale in Lima. Later she had the opportunity to win during several consecutive years the bidding for the concession to sell sweets and juices in a primary school.

Currently Julia has a store in which she sells gifts, toys, writing supplies, etc. She is a member of the community bank "Santa Elena II" , through which she received her first loan of 100 Peruvian sols ($33) with which she bought office supplies to add more variety to her inventory.

With this loan from Manuela Ramos for 800 Peruvian sols ($266), which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy decorative items and toys to replace the merchandise that was stolen a short time ago and additional products that sell well during the holidays.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Julia tiene 38 años de edad, con grado de instrucción superior incompleta y con 4 hijos (actualmente 3 dependen de ella) es una señora muy dinámica y trabajadora, vive en Manuel Arévalo en el Distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad. Ella hace muchos años se dedicaba a la venta de ropa que compraba en Lima al por mayor para a vender por unidad, posteriormente tuvo la oportunidad de ganar varios años consecutivos la licitación para vender golosinas y jugos en el kiosko de un colegio.

Actualmente la señora Julia tiene una tienda en la que vende regalos, juguetes, adornos, útiles de escritorio, etc. La señora julia es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Elena II” en él obtuvo su primer crédito de S/. 100.00 ($33) con los que compró útiles de oficina para surtir su negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.800.00 ($266), el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, está comprando algunas cosas como: adornos y juguetes para reponer la mercadería que le fue robada hace poco y porque son productos que tienen mucha salida en las fiestas de fin de año que se aproximan.

loans.use: Buy decorative items and toys.

loans.name: Rosa Virginia

texts.es:
Rosa is 30 years old, and studied through secondary school. She has four children who are still dependent on her. She lives in the Wichanzao sector in the district of La Esperanza, the province of Trujillo and the department of La Libertad. She is a member of the community bank "Santa Elena II".

Rosa used to spend her days taking care of the household chores. Later she came up with the idea to open a small business, a general store, in her own house. She started the business with the help of her husband, who supported her with a small amount of money. That money served as her initial capital. With her first loan from Manuela Ramos of 300 Peruvian sols ($100) she bought additional products such as detergents, soaps, and toilet paper, to add more variety to her store. Currently Rosa sells bread, soft drinks, vegetables, snacks, eggs, etc.

With this new loan of 400 Peruvian sols ($133), which will be repaid in 4 months, Rosas will buy additional products such as sweets, cookies, and juices, as a way to continue adding variety to her inventory. She dreams of someday having a house with all the modern comforts and a great store.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Rosa tiene 30 años, su grado de instrucción es secundaria completa, tiene cuatro hijos que aun dependen de ella; vive en el sector Wichanzao en el Distrito de La Esperanza, Provincia de Trujillo, Departamento de La Libertad, pertenece al banco comunal “Santa Elena II”.

Anteriormente se dedicaba a los quehaceres del hogar y tuvo la idea de poner un pequeño negocio en su propia casa, una bodeguita. Comenzó con la ayuda de su esposo que le apoyo con una pequeña propina que le sirvió de capital. Con su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 ($100) compró otros productos como detergentes, jabones, papel higiénico para surtir su bodeguita. Actualmente la señora Rosa vende pan, gaseosas, menestras, huevos, etc.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.400.00 soles ($ 133) el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compró otros productos como golosinas, galletas, jugos para continuar surtiendo su bodega. Ella sueña con tener una casa con todas las comodidades y una gran tienda.

loans.use: Purchase of sweets, cookies and juices

loans.name: Lilia Merlinda

texts.es:
Mrs. Lilia is twenty-nine years old and has completed her primary education. She has no children, lives in Caserío Canchachugo, a town in the Usquil district of the department of La Libertad, and is a member of the communal bank, “Canchachugo.” Mrs. Lilia runs her business out of her home where she sells groceries, drinks, motor oil, grains, and so on, but she also travels to sell her products at nearby markets. She began her business with an initial credit of S/.300 ( approx. $100) that she obtained in her communal bank. With this loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.2,000.00, which will be paid back in four months, she will purchase rice, sugar, preserves, candles, and more to stock her store, and also grains wholesale to sell in markets. Mrs. Lilia dreams of going to live on the coast of Trujillo and opening a large business there, where there are more opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Lilia tiene 29 años, su grado de instrucción es primaria completa, aún no tiene hijos; ella vive en el Caserío Canchachugo en el Distrito de Usquil departamento de La Libertad, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Canchachugo”. La señora Lilia tiene su negocio en su propia casa vende abarrotes, lubricantes para motos, bebidas, cereales, etc, pero además viaja a vender sus productos en las ferias cercanas a su comunidad. Ella inició su negocio con su primer crédito de S/. 300 ($ 100) que obtuvo en su bancos comunal. Con el reciente crédito recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,000.00 ($ 664) el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, compró arroz, azúcar, conservas, velas, etc. Para surtir su bodega y además compró cereales al por mayor para llevar a vender en las ferias. La señora Lilia sueño con ir a vivir en la costa (Trujillo) y poner allí un gran negocio considera que en esa ciudad se tiene mayores oportunidades.

loans.use: Purchase highly needed goods, including preserves, wholesale grains, and other groceries.

loans.name: Maria Estela

texts.es:
María is married and has one son. She is a fighting mother, and for more than nine years, she has had a humble shop where she sells coffee and food in the village market. Nevertheless, she has fixed up the facilities of her simple shop to her tastes.

Before she got her stand in the market, María Estela worked in the Central Bank of Nicaragua. She started her shop with an initial investment of $1000.

She has worked with CEPRODEL for more than two and a half years and has an excellent credit record. Thanks to the financing she has received, she has increased her inventory and invested her extra income in the education of her son and her household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Esta señora es casada y tiene un hijo. Ella ha sido una madre luchadora la cual posee desde hace más de9 años un humilde puesto de venta de cafe y comida en el mercado mayoreo. La infraestructura del local sin embargo ella lo ha ido acondicionando a su gusto.

Antes de tener su puesto en el mercado, Marai Estela trabajaba en el Banco Central de Nicaragua. Su puesto inicia con capital de aproximadamente US$ 1000 dólares.

Trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace más de 2½ años con un excelente record crediticio. Gracias al financiamiento ha incrementado su inventario y sus ganacias la ha invertido en la educacion de su hijo y manutencion de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase a showcase for her pastries

loans.name: Santos Victoria

texts.es:
Mrs. Santos is 52 years old, with six children, two of whom are currently dependent on her. Though she never finished primary school, she’s very optimistic about her business. She lives in the Florencia de Mora district of the Trujillo province in the Department of La Libertad. For many years, she has devoted herself to making bread, rolls, and various cakes. Although her business has had some declines, she has always picked herself back up. Now, she sells not only bread, but also basic necessities, such as rice, sugar, oil, milk and so on. Mrs. Santos joined the communal bank “God Guide Our Steps II” at the invitation of her neighbor. She received her first credit for S/300.00 ($100), which she used to purchase flour. With other credits that she received, she made more bread, and her business began to grow; before, she baked bread with just five sacks of flour - now she uses 25 sacks. With a recent loan from Manuela Ramos for S/600.00 ($200) that she will pay in four months, she will purchase groceries such as milk, sugar, rice, oil, and other tools for the bakery. It is her dearest dream to have a large bakery available to her neighborhood and to distribute throughout her district.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Santos a sus 52 años de edad, con grado de instrucción primaria incompleta y con 6 hijos (actualmente 2 dependen de ella), es una señora muy optimista en su negocio. Vive en el Distrito de Florencia de Mora, provincia de Trujillo. Departamento de La Libertad. Ella desde hace muchos años se dedicó a la elaboración de pan, roscas, bizcochos y pasteles a pesar que tuvo algunas caídas en el negocio se ha vuelto a levantar y ahora no solo vende pan sino también algunos productos de primera necesidad como: arroz, azúcar, aceite, leche, etc. La señora Santos ingresó al Bancos Comunal “Dios Guía Nuestros Pasos II” por invitación de una vecina; obtuvo su primer crédito de S/.300.00 con los cuales compró harina. Con los otros créditos que recibió elaboró pan en mayor cantidad y el negocio fue creciendo, antes elaboraba pan solo con 5 sacos de harina y actualmente lo hace con 25 sacos. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 600 soles ($ 200) el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará abarrotes como: leche, azúcar, arroz, aceite, y algunos utensilio para la panadería, ya que su mayor sueño es tener una gran panadería a disposición de su barrio y también distribuir pan en todo su distrito.

loans.use: Purchase of general groceries and tools for the bakery

loans.name: Roine

texts.en: Roine is a young mother of twenty-four years of age and she has one child. Her husband works at the Samoa Water Authority in order to make money. So, she decided to have a small business at home so they will have extra income to help develop their family. Roine sell ice cakes to the people of her community, especially to the school kids. This is with the help of the S.P.B.D. office that lends her the money to fulfill her dreams for her business. She earns more than 200 Tala ($80 US) a week from her sales, and from that she is able to pay her loan and has extra money to support her husband with their family 's financial needs. Roine is looking forward to some more loans to develop her family's standard of living and also to change her business from an ice cake business into a small retail shop.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her ice cake business

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona is an older, hard-working woman of sixty-three years of age. She has eight children, and they are all married and live on their own now. With not so much to do, she owns a small retail shop in her village, where she offers her services to the people of her community. Lona has a strong heart that her business will succeed because of the help she gets from the SPBD office in order to support her business financially. She earns more than six hundred tala a week from her sales, and she uses the money for her loan payment and to support her husband and some of her grandchildren’s education.

loans.use: To buy supplies and inventory for her small shop

loans.name: Sigalu

texts.en: Sigalu is a mother of eight and she is forty-two years of age. She runs a flea market stall in town where she sells her products to make money. Her husband is working also, and she is doing her business to help him out in order to support their children’s education. She has a strong heart that will never fail because her business is backed up by her loan from the S.P.B.D. office. Sigalu earns a profit of 200 Tala ($80 US) a week from her sales, and from that she paid her loan and is able to support her family's financial needs.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her flea market stall

loans.name: Saili

texts.en: Saili is an older businesswoman who never wants to rest or waste any time sitting around. She has seven children, and all of them have graduated from school. Actually, it's her three sons who are doing the hard work, but Saili is the one marketing it and collecting the money. There is no competition in her area, and that’s why Saili is confident in her business. She really appreciates the help of the SPBD office that loaned her the money for her business needs. Saili earns more than 500 Tala ($200 US) a week, and she uses it to pay her loan and  her three sons and helps to meet other family needs. She is also looking forward to some more loans in order to buy more equipment needed in getting the job done because of the increase in customers.

loans.use: To buy a new lawnmower and repair kit

loans.name: Losivale

texts.en: Losivale is thirty-nine years of age and has four children, who are all attending school. She runs a small sewing business at her house in order to get money to support her children’s education. Her husband is also working, but because his salary is not enough to support their family, she decided to use her talent from God as her business to help out with their family needs. Losivale is pleased to have S.P.B.D. supporting her business in terms of money. She is hoping to develop more business, and because of that she is requesting another loan from S.P.B.D.

loans.use: To buy a new electric sewing machine

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en: Sofia is a young woman of twenty-six years of age and has one child. She owns a block at the flea market in town, where she sells her products to the public, especially tourists. The competition is tough, but she has a strong heart because of the help she gets from S.P.B.D. for lending her the money to assist with her business's financial needs. Sofia makes a good profit from her sales every week, and from there she paid her loan and was able to help out with some of her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her flea market stall

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: With her second loan, Victoria hopes to buy more things for her sewing business. This has been a main source of income for her, and she wants to ensure that the business continues in the future. Through SPBD, she has been able to start a sewing business, and this has also meant saving a lot of costs for her, as she is now able to make clothes for her family and children. She also makes her own children’s school uniforms and with the white Sunday that has just passed , new clothes for her children was the least of her worries as she was able to make them herself. She is thankful for the assistance from SPBD and that she now has a business of her own. She will continue to use the help of SPBD in the future where needed to ensure that she sustains her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her sewing business

loans.name: Fogaupolu

texts.en: Making pancakes is Fogaupolu’s expertise, and she hopes to start a business once she gets the funds from SPBD. She plans to target the school nearby, and she will support the business with the money that she makes from the sale of pancakes. Fogaupolu hopes to expand her business to other things, but at this point she is a new kid on the block in the business arena, and she will therefore focus on pancakes to start. She hopes to get more assistance from SPBD in future where needed to further develop her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her pancakes business

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta’s family has been engaged plantation work for some time now. As centre chief for Satapuala, a newly set-up centre, she hopes to utilise this money to help out with the family plantation. Funds from the sale of crops from the plantation will be used to repay the loan, and Elisapeta will continue to ensure that the family plantation is sustained. This is because the plantation is their major source of income, and she wants to ensure that she plays a role in the process of sustaining the family plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina has proposed to start a pork bun business with her first loan. She is grateful that SPBD is able to lend money to unemployed women like herself, and she is looking forward to the opportunity to start this business venture. She would like to expand her business in the future depending on how the pork bun business goes, and she will again seek assistance from SPBD to do that.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her pork bun business

loans.name: Faatalatala

texts.en: Like other members of the centre, Faatalatala has opted to make pancakes as her business. For Faatalatala, making pancakes is easy, and since it is her first time trying a business venture, she has decided to settle for pancakes, as they are not only easy to make, but the materials needed for producing pancakes can be bought easily. She thinks she may be interested in expanding to other food products in the future, depending on how  the pancake business goes. She hopes that SPBD’s assistance will be readily available once she decides to expand in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her pancakes business

loans.name: Tooa

texts.en: This is Tooa’s first loan, and the purpose is to assist with the family’s long-running business. Raising pigs is something Tooa’s family has done for some time now with help from family members. At this point, they need some help with the project. SPBD, as a more flexible lending institution, was the first choice given the strict controls on lending criteria by banks and financial institutions. The other reason for SPBD as a choice had to do with their community-based service and how they come to the village to offer help needed by women who want to go into business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her pig farm

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en: Raising pigs is something that Faaiuga’s family has been doing for some years now. This is her first loan, and the purpose is to help support this family's development. Her family very much depends on this as a source of income, and she wants to ensure that it is sustained. She will utilise her loan to buy some of the materials that they now need for the plantation, and she is really happy for the assistance that SPBD is able to provide to help her and her family.

loans.use: Buying equipment and supplies for her pig farm

loans.name: Ato

texts.en: Ato A. is one of the new members at the borrowing centre that has just started in the village of Satapuala. She plans to open a BBQ business, which has become quite popular these days. Her loan will be utilized to purchase materials for a BBQ stove and to buy meat for her first attempt. She hopes to make some good money in order to repay this loan and to sustain the business. She further hopes to make use of this assistance again in the future should her business need some support.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her barbecue business

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en: Mr. Khalid is a low income vulnerable person. He is 23 and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. For the last five years, Khalid has owned and operated a small food market in the local bazaar of Saatli town. The business is stable. But there are no investment funds to diversify his trading assortment, increase the turnover and therefore improve his income to provide all the necessities of life for his children. Some commercial banks demand collateral for loans. But Khalid has nothing to mortgage. That's why he applied to the Normicro Saatli branch, which disburses loans free of collateral, for a $700 loan. This loan would let him buy and sell a bigger amount of goods and to develop his business.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Emi

texts.en: Emi has been working on a plantation for some time. The assistance from SPBD will be utilized to purchase tools for the plantation, as she is now looking into expanding her crops. She also hopes to be able to have more surplus supply for sale at the market, as this is good money that will help with the upkeep of the plantation business. She says she will continue to seek financial assistance from SPBD to help her with her plantation or in case she decides to expand the business into other areas in future.

loans.use: To buy tools for her plantation

loans.name: Iupeli

texts.en: Iupeli has had her eye on utilizing her sewing skills and knowledge as a form of business venture for her and her family. With this loan she is looking into beginning a new business, namely garment-making, and she hopes to attract customers not just from her village but also from neighbouring villages, or even families that live close by or far from where she lives. It is quite expensive to buy readymade clothes these days, and Iupeli is would now begin to save for buying new clothes as she starts to make garments of her own, not just for use but also for sale. She is looking forward to the business idea and would like to further use the assistance of SPBD (the lender) in the future.

loans.use: To start a sewing business by buying supplies and equipment

loans.name: Teleasau

texts.en: Teleasau’s family plantation has been the main source of food supply and income for her family for quite some time. With the help of SPBD (the lender), she is now able to make her dream come true, and that is utilizing her plantation as an opportunity for a business to facilitate a more stable supply of food for her family and future generations to come. With this money, she will buy some plantation tools and some more crops. She aims to be selling some crops at the market come Christmas and New Year's holidays, as there will be visitors flooding the town to be with families and friends during the Christmas festivities. She is happy with this help as it has allowed people like herself to access some financial support given the strict criteria set by the banks and financial institutions these days.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Otila

texts.en: Otila is looking to use her loan to help her with her plantation business. The plantation business would help her with her family commitments and these include her church commitments as well. At the same time, the business will provide the support she needs for her to pay back this loan, in case she decides to borrow more money in future. There is bound to be problems along the way in her plantation business and therefore she needs to make sure that she manages the plantation and funds well so that she meets her goal of having a successful business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation business

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.en:
Mr. Ilgar is a vulnerable low income person. He is 39, married with three children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Since 1993, Ilgar has been running a mini shop and sells spare parts. Every week Ilgar goes to the wholesale market, which is situated in the capital, Baku, to buy spare parts at reasonable prices. His sales are going well, and he requires more investment to develop the business further. For this purpose, he applied to the Normicro Saatli branch to get a $600 loan. Using these additional funds, he plans to raise his monthly income 30%.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Mr. Zaur has a low income. He is 40, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Zaur owns and operates a mini shop in Saatli town. But, as you can see in the picture, the working capital he has is very limited and Zaur has no opportunity to diversify his assortment of goods for sale. For this purpose, he applied to the Normicro Saatli branch and now is waiting to receive a $500 loan.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Muava

texts.en: Muava is 42-years-old and married with four kids. She is working very hard in her businesses because these are her only source of income. Her loan was used to buy products and tools needed for both businesses. It has been very helpful to the family in different areas such as school fees, food and other family expenses. She hopes to stay long in the loan program.

loans.use: To buy products for her plantation and tools for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Vaeluaga

texts.en: Vaeluaga is married with three kids. She believes that she can make a decent living out of her family’s land, which is why she applied for her loan to buy the necessary products for her plantation business. She sells her crops at the market two times per week and makes a profit of 280 Tala ($112 US) per day, which is very good in her eyes. She hopes to apply for another loan to expand her business and make it more profitable.

loans.use: To buy products and tools for her plantation

loans.name: Elshad

texts.ru:
Elshad was born and raised in the city of Saatli in Azerbaijan. He is 34 and has two children. He was born in a low income family. In 1993 he bought a small piece of land in his village, properly equipped it, set up a tent and started selling timber. The amount of wood he had for sale depended on the time of year. Because of this seasonal property, Elshad's business needed occasional one time investments that would allow him to purchase more wood. In order to be able to increase turnover Elshad came to Normicro, a partner of Kiva, asking to borrow $700. In the future Elshad is hoping to increase both profit and turnover, which will allow him to provide his family with all the necessities.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Ельшад родился и живет в г. Саатлы Азербайджанской Республики. Ему 34, у него двое детей, он выходец из малообеспеченной семьи. В 1993 году он купил небольшую площадку у себя в деревне, оборудовал её, построил навес и начал продавать лесоматериал. Объём продажи зависел от времени года. поэтому бизнес Ельшада нуждался время от времени в разовых вложениях для пополнения товара. Чтобы увеличить объём продаж, Ельшад обращается за кредитом в 700 долларов к Нормикро - партнёру КИВА. После получения кредита он надеется увеличить свою прибыль и обеспечить свою семью всем необходимым.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Sootaiga

texts.en: Sootaiga is a 61-year-old lady who is married with four kids. Even though she is old, she is very driven to run her plantation with the help of her husband and sons. Her loan will be used to buy weed-killers, fertilizers, and gardening tools. She also is planning to build a house for her family on the plantation for living and for storage. She is very happy with the loan program and hopes to stay long in it.

loans.use: To buy tools and products for her plantation

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en: Ms. Elmira is a woman with a low income. She is 20, married with two children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Elmira is a school teacher, but her salary is not enough with two children growing up. Three years ago, she and her sister-in-law (she is pictured) purchased a calf with some money she had saved up. Now Elmira has a tiny herd, which is a great help to support the family. Elmira plans to increase the number of animals to make her income higher. So, she applied for a $500 loan to Normicro Saatli branch. She hopes eventually to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Munasib

texts.ru:
Mr. Munasib A. was born and lives in a village near Saatli, Azerbaijan. He is 21, single. Four years ago, he rented a workshop and opened auto repair business. Periodically, Mr. A. has to replace his tools and renew spare parts inventory. To finance the purchase of tools and parts, he applied for $600 loan from NorMicro, a Kiva partner.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Г-н Мунасиб родился и живёт в деревне около г. Саатлы Азербайджанской Республики. Ему 21, холост. 4 года назад он арендовал помещение и начал ремонтировать автомобили. Т.к. Мунасиб имеет дело с постоянно развивающейся техникой, он вынужден время от времени обновлять свои инструменты, оборудование и прикупать необходимые для работы запасные части. С этой целью он обратился с заявлением о предоставлении ему кредита под бизнес с суммой в 600 долларов в микрокредитную организацию "Нормикро" - партнеру КИВА.

loans.use: To purchase new tools and spare parts

loans.name: Suleyman

texts.ru:
Mr Suleyman was born and raised in a village not from from the city of Saatli, Azerbaijan. He is 21 and is single. 6 years ago he rented a small space and started up a business repairing fuel injection systems in cars. Since Suleyman's personal computer has become obsolete, he decided to purchase a newer one - Pentium 4. This is why he came to Normikro, a partner of Kiva, to borrow $600, which will allow him to do so.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Г-н Сулейман родился и живёт в деревне около г. Саатлы Азербайджанской Республики. Ему 21, холост. 6 года назад он арендовал бокс и начал ремонтировать инжекторную систему впрыскивания топлива для автомобилей. Т.к. персональный компютер Сулеймана уже устарел, он решил приобрести более современный Пентиум 4. С этой целью он обратился с заявлением о предоставлении ему кредита под бизнес с суммой в 600 долларов в микрокредитную организацию "Нормикро" - партнеру КИВА.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Kemale

texts.en:
Ms. Kemale is a woman with a low income. She is 40, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Kemale owns a herd of milk cows. Every day she sells milk to the local milk processing shop. Her son (he is pictured) assists her in breeding the cows. The income from two cows is too low to support the family and to increase her tiny herd. That is why Kemale applied to the Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for a $500 loan to buy one more pure-bred cow to make her monthly income higher. The price of a milk calf is $300, the cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 she plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a cow for milk

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en:
Yashar A. is 41 years old and the father of one child. He is from the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict territory in the Lachin region, situated in the west part of Azerbaijan. Right now he lives in Sumgayit city, with his family. He is the only breadwinner in his family. 

His business consists of video filming. He makes video films in ceremonies of weddings and meetings. He loves his business very much. Yashar wants to buy a computer, but he does not have enough money for this purpose. If he has a computer, he can develop his business further. 

Yashar would like to receive a $500 loan in order to buy a computer and the necessary tools and equipment.  He will repay the loan within 12 months. He hopes eventually to expand his business and improve the living conditions of his family. Yashar will repay his loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To buy a computer and necessary tools and equipments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Hamid

texts.en: Adulloev Hamid has been a butcher for over 11 years. He has his own meat stall in the Ovchikalacha district of Khujand, Tajikistan. He is the father of 3 children. His wife and children help him to fatten sheep for his business. Hamid says that he decided to sell sheep’s meat because it has more nutrients and richer fat then beef, and the price is higher. So his business is going well and he has 4 sheep at home. His future loan from Kiva he wants to spend for buying fodder for them.

loans.use: Purchase of fodder for sheep.

loans.name: Goziboy

texts.en: G. Goziboy has been engaged in the trade of rice for over 3 years. He has three children and they all go to school. His wife is a housewife, so he supports all of them. His business is located in the Ovchikalacha district of Khujand in the food market. His business place is crowded every day and he says that he has a lot of clients. The turnover of his capital is good. But presently he needs extra capital to increase his volume of rice, as now is the season for harvesting rice and the wholesale price for this product is lower than at other times. He wants to make reserves for future trade.

loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.en: Nargiza is one of the active clients of Microinvest. Her starting capital was about $100. She started her business one year ago in the Ovchikalacha food market, in one of the districts of Khujand. She sold cookies from a local bakery. Step by step, she increased her working capital and started to buy other food products from the wholesale market in Istaravshan, Khujand. Today she has a stable profit from a wide assortment of goods. Her future loan she wants to spend to further develop her business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline D. is happily married with two children. She is 40 years old, and is from Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells used clothes and she has been in this business since 1990. She needs a loan of $400 to buy more used clothes for sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Ijeoma

texts.en: Ijeoma O. is 27 years old and married. She hails from Ajamgbadi, in Lagos State, Nigeria. Ijeoma sells motorcycle parts to support her family and children. Ijeoma has been in the business since 1999, and she would like a loan of $450 to purchase motorcycle parts for sale.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycle part for sale

loans.name: Kimiyo

texts.en:
T. Kimiyo is a very lively person. She is 42 years old and has 4 children. Her business is the trade of sportwear for men. Her business is located in the center of the open air clothing market in Ovchikalacha, in Khujand. She buys her goods from the Istaravshan clothing market every week. Her current turnover is fast and she is very satisfied that her business is developing.

When she heard about the Kiva program she said that it is a very great activity which helps thousands of people to make their life better. She will be very happy to be funded by foreign lenders.

All her profits are spent for family needs and she does not have an opportunity to put a roof on her business place. It will cost her about 1000 som ($300). She hopes that Kiva will help her to do this.

loans.use: Put a roof on her clothing stall

loans.name: Amaka

texts.en: Amaka O. is 30 years old, married and has 3 children; she lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sews and also sells clothes. She has been in this business since 2000 and she is in needs of a loan of $400 to enable her buy more machines and tailoring material.

loans.use: To buy more machine & tailoring material for sale

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina M. is 34 years old, and married with 4 children. She lives in the Lagos State of Nigeria. She sells foods and she has kept her business since the year 2000. She has been an LAPO client for the past 3 years. She needs the loan of $400 to buy more food supplies.

loans.use: To buy more food stuff for sale

loans.name: Abdulla

texts.en:
A. Abdulla is 54 years old and a father of 4 children. He is from the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict territory of the Gubadli region, situated in the west part of Azerbaijan. Right now he lives in Sumgayit city with his family. He is the only breadwinner in his family. He began his business 7 years ago. He began his business with $200. He started selling a small variety of baby clothes. With this small business and only $200 in working capital, he could hardly earn enough money to meet his family's food and important consumption needs. He had difficulty in covering other family consumption needs for medication, clothes, school, etc.

Having borrowed a loan amount of $700 from Normicro, he rented a shop. The second time he borrowed $1000 and expanded his business. The loans were paid back on time.

Now, he needs a $1000 loan in order to further develop his business, to buy more suits and baby clothes, to increase his business, and to improve his family’s living condition with this additional income. He will repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: to buy other sort of suits and baby clothes, to increase his business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy M. is married with nine children. She is 55 years of age and hails from Ajanmgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and has been in this business since 1999. She requests a loan of $250 to buy more foodstuffs for sale. She thanks you in advance for your help.

loans.use: To buy more food stuff for sale

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo J. is age 27, a single woman who has been in business since 2004. She lives in Igbolerin, which is in Lagos Stare, Nigeria. She rents out videos. She needs the loan $400 to buy more videos to rent.

loans.use: To buy more videos for sale and rent

loans.name: Mutiato

texts.en: Mutiato A. is a 45 years old married mother with 4 children. She lives in Lagos State Nigeria. She sells provision and food and has been into this business since the year 1997.  She needs a loan $400 to buy more provisions and food for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provision & foodstuff  for sale

loans.name: Gbemisola

texts.en: Gbemisola A. is 48 years old, married, and has 6 children. She hails from Ibgolerin, in Lagos State, Nigera. Gbemisola sells foods in her local market to support her family, and has been doing so since 1992. Gbemisola would like a loan of $400 to purchase a wider variety of foods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food stuffs for sale

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo O. is a 45 year old married mother of 4. She is from Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks, provision, food and has machine for grinding of tomatoes for her customers. She has been in this business since 1987. She is requesting for a loan of $625 to buy more drinks, provisions, food for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, provisions, foodstuffs

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria O. is originally from Igbelerin, a rural part in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She is married and has five children. She travels to other neighboring villages to buy cassava for processing local food.  She has been in business since 1997.  She is a LAPO member.  She needs the loan of $400 to buy more cassava to grow and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more cassava for the processing of Santana

loans.name: Omowumin

texts.en: “LAPO has been a source of blessing for my business”, says O. who lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. O. is 50 years old, and has 3 children, and sells foodstuffs at her local market. She has been in this business since 1977, and needs the loan of $400 to purchase more foodstuffs for her sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en: Bolaji A.  is a 45 year old married mother of 4 children. She lives in Lagos State of Nigeria. She sells electrical materials to people living in her community. She learned the business for 2 months after which she started her own in 1977. She is a LAPO member. She is in needs of a loan of $400 to buy more electrical materials to sell.

loans.use: To buy more electrical materials for sale

loans.name: Modupe-Ola

texts.en: Thirty-three years ago Modupe-Ola T. was born in a poor village in Lagos State, Nigeria. Against the odds she has taken nothing but her ingenuity and work-ethic and made it into a successful salon business. She has successfully grown the business over the last five years, but now she needs your help to further improve her salon. A loan of only 400 USD from you would allow her to buy the supplies she needs to prosper. She is married and mother of two young children.

loans.use: To buy hair products such as dye and hair relaxer necessary to sucess in the salon buissness

loans.name: Bahar

texts.en:
M. Bahar is a refugee from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory in the Gubadli region, situated in the west part of Azerbaijan. She is 48 years old and a mother of 2 children. She keeps very busy with her private business of sewing client's clothes. She began her business 18 years ago with $300. At first, it was very difficult for her to cover all her family's consumption needs. Having borrowed a loan amount of $400 from Normicro, she rented an area of her business.
