loans.use: To repair the car

loans.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Duong Thi B., 47 years old, has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva partner) since 1997. She started with a loan of 30USD to buy and sell agricultural products. She spent most of the profit from that loan on her everyday living expenses, and was able to save a small amount. After three years borrowing from TYM Fund, Mrs. B. has gained more confidence to borrow more money to buy old barrels and discarded plastic, etc to sell to recycle companies. From bare hands, Mrs. B. is now an owner of a recycle store where she has three employees working for her, each gets a wage of 60 USD per month. Each month Mrs. B. earns about 375USD. Thanks to the loan from TYM Fund, she was able to build a convenient, three-storey house. She would like to borrow 950USD to buy van to transport garbage.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Dương Thị Bảy, 47 tuổi là thành viên tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1997. Khi mới vào Quỹ chị khởi đầu với mức vốn 30USD dùng vào việc buôn bán nông sản phẩm, thu nhập chỉ để chi tiêu vặt và tích lũy một phần nhỏ. Sau 3 năm tham gia vay vốn của Quỹ, chị đã mạnh dạn vay mức vốn cao cùng với vốn tự có của gia đình chuyển sang thu mua các loại thùng phi cũ, nhựa phế thải...đem bán cho các cơ sở thu mua lớn. Từ chỗ chỉ là mua đi bán lại cho các chủ khác đến nay chị đã trở thành một chủ cơ sở thu mua phế liệu tại nhà và có 3 công nhân làm thuê mỗi tháng trả lương 60USD/người. Thu nhập bình quân một tháng của gia đình là 375USD. Nhờ vào hoạt động vay vốn của Quỹ để kinh doanh nên gia đình chị đã có thể xây được 1 ngôi nhà 3 tầng khang trang, có đầy đủ tiện nghi sinh hoạt. Hiện tại chị mong muốn được vay thêm 950USD từ Quỹ để mua ô tô vận chuyển hàng.

loans.use: Buy van to transport garbage

loans.name: Luong Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Lương Thị Liên is 53 years old. She is a member of TYM fund since April 1996. After 11 years she now owns a viable farming business that really helps to lift up her family living condition. They exploit a farm that has 2 fish ponds (3264 square feet each), a 1/2 acre field of jasmine shrubs and fruit trees, a peep of 200 chickens for meat. Things have changed for the better since she joined the fund, the living condition had improved. She had built a house, she can afford to buy things that she needs. The income from her farm is about 190 USD a month. She's requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy chicken feed and breeding species.

Translaled from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Là thành viên tham gia Quỹ tháng 4 năm 1996, sau 11 năm tham gia chị Lương Thị Liên, 53 tuổi, đã có một mô hình kinh tế gia đình phát triển tốt. Hiện nay gia đình chị đã xây dựng được trang trại với qui mô lớn có 2 sào ao thả cá, 5 sào hoa nhài và cây ăn quả, 200 con gà thịt. Từ khi tham gia quỹ gia đình chị đã có rất nhiều thay đổi về kinh tế như xây dựng nhà, công trình phụ, mua sắm trang thiết bị sinh hoạt trong gia đình. Mức thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị là 190USD/tháng. Hiện tại chị đang xin vay 1200 USD để mua thức ăn gia súc và con giống.

loans.use: Buy chicken feed, chickens, young fishes

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Ngô Thị C., 54 years old, lives in Trung Giã village. She is a member of branch 2 in Sóc Sơn since 1995. Her first loan was only 30 USD. In later rounds she was able to secure bigger loans which was invested in a farm supplies business. The revenue from this business is about 150 USD a month. Since she is single, she does not invest her money in a house nor spend it on expensive things. She saves all her money for her retirement. This time she requests a loan of 1200 USD to stock up her farm supplies.

Translaled from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Ngô Thị C., 54 tuổi, sống tại xã Trung Giã là thành viên của chi nhánh 2 Sóc Sơn từ năm 1995. Bắt đầu với mức vốn đầu tiên là 30USD đến các vòng vốn sau chị đều vay mức vốn tối đa để sử dụng vào mục đích buôn bán các mặt hàng nông sản như lạc, vừng, đỗ… Công việc kinh doanh này mang lại cho chị mức thu nhập là: 150USD/tháng. Là một phụ nữ độc thân nên chị không đầu tư vào kiến thiết nhà cửa, mua các vật dụng có giá trị trong gia đình mà chị chỉ tích luỹ tiền để tiết kiệm cho tuổi già. Ở vòng vốn này chị xin vay 1200USD để kinh doanh hàng nông sản.

loans.use: Buy agricultural product

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Her husband passed away a few years ago. Ms Ngô Thị Lợi, 48 years old, has been raising her 2 children by herself and now they are all grown up. She joined TYM fund in 1995, her first loan was only 30 USD which was invested in a morning breakfast service. In subsequent loans, she has been able to qualify for maximum amount which was invested in a clothing store. The investment has been fruitful. Now 12 years later, she has built a nice & cozy 60 m2 house (540 square feet). Her monthly income is about 187 USD. She's requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy more products for her breakfast service, winter clothes for her store for the coming cold season.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chồng mất từ mấy năm trước, chị Ngô Thị Lợi, 48 tuổi, một mình nuôi 2 con khôn lớn trưởng thành. Là thành viên tham gia Quỹ năm 1995, năm đầu chị vay vốn mức 30USD bán hàng ăn sáng. Các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị vay mức tối đa bán hàng quà và buôn bán quần áo mang lại những hiệu quả kinh tế tốt cho gia đình. Cho đến nay, sau 12 năm tham gia Quỹ chị đã xây nhà mới diện tích 60 m2 khang trang đẹp đẽ. Hiện tại mức thu nhập bình quân hàng tháng của chị Lợi là 187USD. Chị đang xin vay thêm 1200USD để mua thêm thực phẩm và quần áo rét bán cho mùa đông tới.

loans.use: Buy foodstuff, winter garment.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. joined TYM Fund in 2000. However, her husband did not agree with her decision. That’s why Mrs. T. decided to stop borrowing from TYM Fund in 2003, so that her situation would not affect other members in her group. In 2006, she again borrowed money from TYM Fund (Kiva partner). This time she wants to borrow 575USD to expand her tailoring shop. Since her shop is located in the center of the village, it is often very crowded. Although very busy with her job, Mrs. T. still spends a lot of time taking care of her children. She brings them to school and takes them home everyday. Her children are very good and learn well at school. Now her income is 125USD per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyến Thị Thường tham gia Quỹ năm 2000, nhưng sau một thời gian do không có được sự nhất trí của chồng nên năm 2003 chị xin ra khỏi nhóm để không ảnh hưởng đến nhóm, cụm. Năm 2006 chị xin quay trở lại cụm và được tham gia vay vốn với chính sách vốn mới được thử nghiệm tại chi nhánh. Vốn vòng này chị xin vay 575 USD đầu tư vào cửa hàng may quần áo. Chị thuê cửa hàng tại trung tâm của thôn nên lúc nào cũng tấp nập khách tới thăm và may quần áo. Mặc dù thời gian làm việc rất bận rộn nhưng chị vẫn dành thời gian đưa đón con đi học và chăm sóc các cháu chu đáo, nên các cháu rất ngoan chăm học và vâng lời mẹ. Hiện tại mức thu nhập hàng tháng của chị là 125USD.

loans.use: Buy clothes

loans.name: Ni Luh Gede Wirawati

texts.id:
Although a wife of public official, Wirawati did not want to stay at home only, while taking care of her child of 2 years Wirawati raised 1 mother pig. After 6 months the pig bore 6 piglets and 2 months later the piglets sold for Rp. 250.000 (USD25), - each. Cost of feed required of Rp. 10.000 (USD1) daily. Temporary, the mother pig is leased beneath a tree while Wirawati renovated the pen, because formerly the pen was made of bamboo, now permanent so that it is easier to clean. This loan from Dinari will be used to purchase 5 piglets for growth and the balance for feed/supplies. The income will be used for her child’s education, currently in SD (elementary school).

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Walaupun sebagai istri seorang karyawan swasta, tapi Wirawati tak mau tinggal diam dirumah saja, sambil mengasuh anaknya yang masih balita umur 2 tahun Wirawati memelihara babi dibelakang rumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Wirawati membeli 1 ekor induk babi. Setelah 6 bulan dipelihara babinya mempunyai anak sebanyak 6 ekor dan 2 bulan anak babinya sudah siap dijual dengan harga Rp.250.000,-per ekor. Biaya pakan yang diperlukan Rp. 10.000,- perhari. Untuk sementara waktu, babinya diikat dibawah pohon karena Wirawati sedang merenovasi kandangnya supaya bagus, karena dulu kandangnya bambu, sekarang sudah permanen agar mudah membersihkannya. Pinjaman dari Dinari ini akan dipakai untuk membeli 5 ekor anak babi untuk penggemukan dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan. Keuntungannya dipakai untuk biaya pendidikan anaknya yang masih duduk dibangku SD.

loans.use: Purchase five mother pig and feed (Membeli lima ekor bibit babi dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Komang Mariani

texts.id:
Ni Komang Mariani has two children, one currently in university that forces Mariani to work more for the sake of to support her child’s aspiration. Mariani wish that when her child succeeds it would alter their life. For that Mariani chose pig farming as it is very suitable to be carried out in the village. With the initial funding of Rp. 2.500.000 (USD270), - Mariani rear 2 mother pigs and 5 piglets for growth. Profit from each piglet, after paying for feed is Rp. 80.000 (USD8.50). This profit will be used to pay for the child’s education. Seeing her development Mariani need additional funding which will be used to purchase mother pig thus generating larger profit as each month Mariani is able to harvest and sell the pigs.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Komang Mariani memiliki dua orang anaknya, salah satunya kini sedang duduk dibangku kuliah yang mengharuskan Mariani harus bekerja lebih keras lagi demi mendukung cita –cita anaknya. Mariani sangat ingin sekali melihat anaknya berhasil dan nantinya bisa merubah kehidupan mereka. Untuk itu Mariani memilih usaha beternak karena usaha inilah yang paling cocok dijalankan di daerah pedesaan. Dengan modal awal Rp. 2.500.000,- Mariani memelihara 2 ekor induk dan 5 babi penggemukan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh perekor mencapai Rp. 80.000,- setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Dari keuntungan inilah yang nantinya dipakai untuk biaya sekolah anaknya.Sekarang melihat perkembangan dari usahanya Mariani membutuhkan tambahan modal yang akan dipergunakan untuk membeli induk babi agar mendatangkan keuntungan yang lebih besar dan diupayakan agar setiap bulan Mariani bisa panen dan menjual babinya

loans.use: Purchase mother pig (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Ni Putu Yuliarini

texts.id:
Ni Putu Yuliarini a hardworking lady. Besides working in LPD (an organization in the village that handles finances), Ni Putu Yuliarini runs a stall in her home and also rear pigs. With the initial funding Rp. 2.000.000 (USD200), - Ni Putu Yuliarini rear 2 mother pigs and 5 piglets for growth. Cost of feed required daily is Rp. 20.000 (USD2). Besides feeding a mixture of rice and bran, Ni Putu Yuliarini also feed leaves like banana leaves, taro leaves, and banana stalk. Profit earned of Rp. 80.000 (USD8.50), - per pig, after deducting cost of feed. Currently Ni Putu Yuliarini is rearing 4 pigs for growth and plans to purchase 5 piglets with the funding from Dinari. Profit earned will be used to pay for her two sons’ education still in school.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Putu Yuliarini seorang wanita pekerja keras. Disamping bekerja di LPD ( sebuah lembaga di desa yang menangani keuangan ), Ni PutuYuliarini juga membuka usaha warung dirumahnya dan usaha beternak babi. Dengan modal awal Rp. 2.000.000,- Ni Putu Yuliarini memelihara 2 ekor induk dan 5 penggemukan. Biaya pakan yang diperlukan Rp. 20.000,- perhari. Disamping memberi dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Ni Putu Yuliarini juga memberikan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang, daun talas, dan juga batang pisang. Keuntungan yang diperoleh Rp. 80.000,- perekor, setelah dikurangi biaya pakan. Sekarang Ni Putu Yuliarini baru memelihara 4 ekor babi penggemukan dan berencana membeli 5 ekor anak babi lagi setelah mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk biaya pendidikan kedua anaknya yang masih duduk dibangku sekolah.

loans.use: Purchase 5 piglets (Membeli 5 ekor anak babi)

loans.name: Ni Putu Juli Antari

texts.id:
With the limited knowledge Ni Putu Juli Antari possessed initially courageously started pig farming. Antari chose this effort because she wanted to assist her husband who works as a farmer fulfills the family’s needs. With funding Rp. 1.000.000 (USD100), - Antari purchased 4 pigs for growth. After rearing for 4 months each pig can be sold for Rp. 800.000 (USD85), - four for Rp. 3.200.000 (USD340), - . Profit from each amounting to Rp. 200.000 (USD21), - . This profit will be used to pay for the children’s education. Their home built on their land is basic. Antari plans to use this loan from Dinari to purchase more mother pigs thus increasing profit which can be used to renovate their home.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan keterbatasan pengetahuan yang dimiliki awalnya Ni Putu Juli Antari memberanikan diri untuk memulai usaha beternak babi. Usaha ini dipilih karena Antari sangat ingin membantu suaminya yang bekerja sebagai petani untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Dengan modal Rp. 1.000.000,- Antari membeli 4 ekor babi untuk dipelihara sebagai penggemukan. Setelah dipelihara selama 4 bulan per ekor babi laku terjual seharga Rp. 800.000,-. Empat ekor Rp. 3.200.000,-. Keuntungan yang diperoleh perekor sebesar Rp. 200.000,-. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk biaya sekolah anak –anaknya. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dan bangunan yang cukup sederhana. Antari berencana pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari dipakai untuk membeli bibit babi lebih banyak lagi agar keuntungan yang didapat bisa bertambah yang nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk merenovasi rumahnya menjadi lebih baik lagi dari sekarang.

loans.use: Purchase mother pig (Membeli bibit babi)

loans.name: Ni Luh Wiryawati

texts.id:
Luh Wiryawati has a husband whose name is I Made Nama Yasa who works as a building laborer. As a laborer income is not constant, since he only get paid when work was there, and no income if no work. However live continues, and needs daily cost. To help her husband, Wiryawati decides to start pig farming, since this business could be done while taking care of children and house. With an initial capital of Rp 1,000,000 (about US$105) Wiryawati bought 1 mother pig that she raised for 6 months. After 6 months, the mother pig gave birth to 6 piglets; after raising these piglets for another 2 months, those piglets were sold at Rp250,000 (about US$26)/piglet. Profit was used to pay for schooling expenses for her 2 children who are still in Grade school, and also to cover family needs. Now with capital help from Dinari, Wiryawati could add the mother pig, and fattening piglets. With the hope that expected profit could increase family well being.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Luh Wiryawati memiliki suami yang bernama I Made Nama Yasa yang bekerja sebagai buruh bangunan. Sebagai buruh, pendapatan penghasilan tak tentu setiap harinya karena jika suaminya mendapatkan pekerjaan baru mendapatkan uang tetapi jika tidak, maka tidak mendapatkan uang. Sedangkan hidup harus terus berjalan dan membutuhkan biaya setiap hari. Untuk membantu suaminya Wiryawati memutuskan untuk memilih usaha beternak babi karena usaha ini bisa dijalankan sambil menggurus rumah dan juga mengurus anak –anaknya. Dengan modal awal Rp. 1.000.000 Wiryawati membeli 1 induk babi dan dipelihara selama 6 bulan. Setelah 6 bulan dipelihara induk babi mempunyai anak 6 ekor, setelah dipelihara selama 2 bulan anak babinya laku terjual dengan harga perekor Rp.250.000.- Keuntungannya dipakai untuk membiayai pendidikan kedua anaknya yang masih duduk dibangku SD dan juga untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Sekarang dengan bantuan modal usaha yang didapat dari Dinari Wiryawati dapat membeli tambahan jumlah induk dan juga bibit penggemukan. Dengan harapan keuntungan yang diperoleh meningkat demi kesejahteraan keluarga mereka.

loans.use:
To buy pig feedstock & feed

Membeli bibit babi dan pakan

loans.name: Twiga Group

texts.en:
Prosper P., age 55, is married with 7 children (ages 30, 25, 20, 17, 15, 10 and 7). Prosper has been working as a part-time construction mason for over 35 years. From this job, he earns around $320-360 per month. He and his wife also run a fruit and vegetable stand, which they started 7 years ago. This business makes about $18 a day. The stand, opened from 7am to 8pm, attracts around 60 customers a day.

Prosper is the leader of the loan group “Twiga” (Swahili for “giraffe”), which has 16 members. The other members of his group have businesses dealing with sales of food, table tops, clothing, wood work, cattle, fish, and charcoal. Prosper knows every member of his group personA., since they are all neighbors and have businesses in the same locality. This group borrowed a previous loan together (minus 8 members who were replaced after the loan was repaid), and was able to pay it back successfully. They now hope for a new loan.

Prosper used the previous loan to buy fruits and vegetables for his stand. With the new loan, he hopes to purchase more stock and also enlarge his stall.

loans.use: To expand businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his current operations

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her current stock and buy a weighing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock of dry maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her stock and expand her store

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
ESTHER L. is a 46 year old widow with 5 children who are all in school. She takes care of her elderly mother, to educate her children and also provide for their basic needs, Esther sells dry maize to individuals and institutions in Kericho.she has been in this business for the last 10 years and has acquired business management training from ebony foundation.she wants to expand her business and also sell to other retailers in the area, to succeed in this noble idea she is requesting for a loan of US$ 1200 which she intends to use as follows;US$ 800 to purchase extra stock and US$ 400 to expand her store.
Esther is determined and she is of good character hence the ability to repay the loan.

loans.use: to increase her current stock

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
My name is Seema B. and I'm from a small town in Pakistan. I am married with six children. My group raises livestock and sells their milk in nearby villages. At present, we have four cows, four buffaloes and two goats. We sell approximately 50 kg of milk daily. Our business has grown over the years with the loans we have borrowed from Asasah, a microfinance institution, based in Pakistan. Now we want to buy another cow to increase the milk production. 



We have been friends for years and have acquired various loans together, where we accept repayment responsibility for each other’s loans. My group members are: Aphan B., who owns a few cows and sells their milk; Hamida B., who also sells milk to her neighborhood clients; and Aziz B., whose husband runs a grocery store.  I would like to help all of them so that our community can prosper and women's voices are heard in their houses. We are applying for a loan of $1025 to buy another cow for our dairy business.

loans.use: Expand the group's dairy business by buying another cow

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
My name is Bushra B.. I am married and have five children. I live with my family in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, which is about an hour and a half away from the nearest city. My husband is a daily wage laborer and I sell milk to make a living. I own two cows but now I would like to buy an additional cow, because my husband does not generate a steady source of income and I would like to increase the milk production of my business.



I have many friends in my neighborhood and they all are the members of my loan group. All of us have taken two loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution and invested in our businesses. My group members are: Zainab B., who sells milk to her clients from nearby villages; Anum B. and her husband, who buy milk from various providers and sell it in a nearby city;  Zohran B., whose husband operates a restaurant; and Mukhtar B., who also raises livestock and sells milk. They all are hardworking entrepreneurs and play an important role in bringing income to their families.

loans.use: Buy another cow for the dairy business

loans.name: Iqbal's Group

texts.en:
My name is Iqbal B. and I'm from Kot Radha Kishan, a small town in Pakistan. I am married with seven children. I embroider clothes on order and my husband is a farmer. He owns a piece of land where he grows seasonal vegetables. He also owns three cows and sells their milk for additional income. He would like to buy another cow and increase milk production. With the increase in profits, I will collect a dowry for my daughter, who is getting married next year. 
There are other women like me in my neighborhood, who need loans to expand their enterprises. My group members are: Shahnaz B., whose  husband is a cloth merchant; Bashiran B. and her husband, who raise cows and sell their milk to make a living; Sakina B. and her husband, who also sell milk; and Sughran B. whose husband runs a small restaurant where he sells tea and breakfast. We have all taken loans before and repaid them because we are all hardworking people who invest the money back into the business. We are associates who accept the responsibility for each other’s loans.

loans.use: To buy a cow and increase the milk production of the business

loans.name: Bilqees' Group

texts.en:
My name is Bilqees B.. I was born in Chichawatni and moved to Kot Rahda Kishan after my marriage. I have two daughters and one son. I am planning to send them to school when they are old enough. My husband works at a yarn factory for a meager income. I have two cows and sell their milk to supplement my husband’s income. My children are growing and so are their expenses. We need to increase our household income so that we can enroll all of our children in a school.
I would like to borrow $675 with my friend who is also my neighbor. We have always helped each other in times of need. My group member is Irshad B., whose husband is a shoemaker.

loans.use: To buy a cow and increase milk production for my business

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mr. P. Phoeun was married in 1987 and has four children, two sons and two daughters. He started his transportation service business in 2004 with his van. He also buys and resells cows from one province and another. His wife weaves silk at home.

He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $1,000. He will use this loan to expand his business of purchasing and reselling cows in Kampong Speu province.

loans.use: To purchase and resell cows in Kampong Speu province

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Srey was married in 1988 and has three daughters. She has been in the business of weaving silk since 1988. She learned to weave silk from her mother one year before she got married. Her eldest daughter also weaves silk at home, and her other two daughters are studying at high school in the village. Her husband grows rice and looks after the cows.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $100. She will use this loan to repair the water pumping machine for her husband's business of growing rice.

loans.use: To repair water pumping machine

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Sok was married in 2000 and has one son. She learned to run her wedding fashion and beauty business from the Angkor Training Centre in Phnom Penh, and has been in business since 1989. In addition, she weaves silk at home. Her husband, Mr. NHIM Chanthorn, repairs boats, and also grows rice and feeds livestock at his farm.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA before, and is now asking for a loan in the amount of $800. She will use this loan to purchase additional silk cloths and other wedding jewelry to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional silk cloths and other wedding costumes.

loans.name: Samoe

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Samoe was married in 1990 and has four children, three sons and one daughter. She began her farming after she got married. In addition, she has been weaving silk at home since 2005. Her husband is construction worker.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA once before, and is now asking for a loan in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to purchase seeds and rent more land to expand her vegetable plantation.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and rent land to expand her vegetable plantation

loans.name: Yaren

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Yaren was married in 1993 and has three sons. She began her business of selling mixed grill meat in 2006. Before she started her small restaurant business, she used to weave silk at her home. Her husband is a construction worker, and all of her children are studying.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already, and is now asking for another loan in the amount of $450. She will use the amount of $250 to purchase a motorbike and $200 to expand her restaurant business.

loans.use: To expand bar and grill business and purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her stock

loans.name: Vary

texts.en:
Mrs. U. Vary is 39 years old, and she and her husband married in 1990. They have four children, all of whom are in school studying in grades 3-9. They live in a fertile farming area along the Tonle Bassac (river), a tributary of the Mekong, several kilometers south of Phnom Penh. She is requesting this first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $800. She will use this loan to purchase a contract for the future harvest of two banana farms in her village. In 3 to 4 months she will sell them at a price higher than the agreed-upon price she pays today.

She has been farming since she was a teenager and buying and selling bananas for more than 15 years. Many people of Chinese descent live in Cambodia. During the celebration of Chinese New Year, bananas are used as a traditional offering and the price increases greatly. Vary also grows jasmine for use in Buddhist ceremonies and longan, a fruit similar to lychee. She sells these to retailers at one of the large markets in Phnom Penh.

Vary’s long-term hopes are to keep growing her business. She explained that the loan will allow her to buy a greater number of banana contracts for future sale, allowing her to make more income. As is typical in Cambodia, she plans to use any extra income to help her children continue their studies.

loans.use: To buy a contract to purchase banana tree output from two village plots now at a specified price.  She will harvest in 3-4 months and sell the bananas at the future market rate.

loans.name: Sophin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophin L. (age 35) and her husband (age 34) have been married for 10 years. They have 2 children, one boy and one girl. The girl who is the eldest, studies in school in their village. They live in a fertile farming area along the Tonle Bassac (river), a tributary of the Mekong, several kilometers south of Phnom Penh. Her husband drives a multi-person motorbike taxi called a “remorque”, transporting workers to and from the many nearby garment factories. She is requesting this second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $600. She will use the funds from the loan to purchase a motorbike for transporting fish that she resells in her village. Any remaining money she will use for buying fish for re-sale.

She has been buying and reselling fish since 1997. Fish is, by far, the most common source of protein in Cambodia. Sophin says she typically sells about three kilograms per day. Over the course of the year, she says she sells perhaps 7 or 8 different kinds, depending which type is in season. Depending on the kind of fish, the sales price ranges from 5,000-12,000 Riel (US $1.25-$3.00) per kilogram and she nets about 50% profit. Sophin usually goes to a nearby village on the edge of a large lake to purchase her fish. In the event she can’t buy what she needs there, she travels to the larger district market to buy. She then returns to re-resell her inventory at the small market that springs up along the road in her village. In the event she can’t sell everything she buys, she goes door-to-door in her village to move the remaining stock.

Sophin’s long-term hopes are to keep growing her business. She explained that the loan will allow her to travel to and from where she buys fish much more easily. She also hopes that she’ll be able to save more money to improve her family’s life.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport fish and to buy fish for re-sale in her village.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mrs. L. Soy (age 35) and her husband PHOM Ponlok (age 51) have been married for 12 years. They have 5 children, 3 boys and two girls. Three of the children study in school. They live in a farming area along National Road 2, several kilometers south of Phnom Penh. Her husband (third from left in photo) serves in the Cambodian Army. Soy herself (not pictured), works in a nearby garment factory. Even though monthly wages of garment workers is about US $45-$50, it is considered a good job in Cambodia. Women make up 85%-90% of the factory workforces.

She is requesting this, her second loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $800. Her family will use the funds from the loan to build a small shop in front of their house for selling groceries and other household goods. They will use the remainder of the loan to purchase inventory for the shop. After the store, which is partially built, is finished, their eldest son (far right of photo) and Soy’s mother-in-law (far left of photo) will work there. They will travel to the district market to buy inventory such as cooking oil, sugar, rice, laundry detergent, dish soap, and children’s snacks.

loans.use: To build a small shop in front of their house and to purchase groceries and other goods for inventory.

loans.name: Chantorn

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Chantorn (age 53) and her husband married in 1979. They have five children, four of whom still live at home as well as one son-in-law and two grandchildren. One daughter studies at college. They are requesting their first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $800. They will use this loan to purchase dishware, utensils, and food supplies for her cafe/restaurant.

While Chantorn’s husband works as a security guard, his job for the past eight years, the family’s primary source of income is the food and drink stand she operates in front of their house. She’s been doing this for the past three years and her business continues to grow. She told us that she learned to cook professionally during an eight-year period in the office of a Cambodian senator. Her current clientele are comprised of people from her village and passers-by on the road that runs past her shop. On a good day she can serve up to 50 customers.

She currently prepares and sells basic noodle and soup dishes commonly referred to as “Khmer Noodles”. She hopes to refine her shop and menu so she can sell a range of more complex and expensive fare referred to as “Chinese Noodles”. The main difference between these two styles of cooking comes from the expense of ingredients, the method of preparation, and formality of dining. A typical serving of Khmer Noodles costs about US $0.25 while a serving of Chinese Noodles costs $0.63.

Chantorn’s main goal in growing her business is to better support her one child who studies at college.

loans.use: To purchase dishware, utensils, and food supplies for her business.

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Yoeun, 37, has been married since 1988 and has five children, ages 6-18. One day a week she buys fresh jasmine flowers and bananas from a neighboring village to resell at markets in Phnom Penh. On other days, she stays at home taking care of her children. Her husband, 38, has been a fish seller for the past 20 years. Every day, he travels to a neighboring village where he buys fish directly from the fishermen. He drives an old motorbike-scooter around the commune (a collection of 3 villages), reselling the fish door-to-door.

Yoeun is requesting a second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $600. She will use this loan to purchase a new motorbike-scooter for her husband's business to replace the old, unreliable one he is currently using. She also plans to use this new motorbike for her weekly trips into Phnom Penh. A portion of the loan will also be used to build a new, thatched home for the family. This new home, will only take one month to complete and they are already preparing the foundations. The balance of the loan will be used to purchase additional jasmine and bananas for Yoeun to resell.

Of their five children, all currently attend the local schools and three of them also take English lessons at a private school. With the help of this new loan, Yoeun hopes to continue expanding their businesses and save money to ensure their children are able to pursue a higher education.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike-scooter to sell fish, buy fresh flowers to resell, and build a new thatched home.

loans.name: Ross

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Ross, 51, has been married since 1981 and has two children. She lives in a modest home south of Phnom Penh along National Road 2. This area is very fertile and well-suited to growing fruit and flowers. Like some women in her village, Ross buys fresh jasmine flowers and bananas from a neighboring village to resell at markets in Phnom Penh. Bananas are a year-round treat in Cambodia and a few different varieties are grown. The jasmine flowers are typically sold to women who make offering arrangements used in Buddhist ceremonies and for jasmine tea.

Ross is requesting a third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to purchase jasmine and bananas in bulk to resell. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy additional products for her daughter, 23, to sell at the mini-mart in front of the family home while she tends to her two young children. Ross' son, 17, is currently studying at the local school and also attending night classes. Ross hopes that this new loan will enable her family to prosper and secure a better future for them all.

loans.use: To purchase fresh flowers and bananas to resell.

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Poverty remains widespread in Thiaroye-sur-Mer but the hardworking inhabitants struggle daily to improve their lot. The five entrepreneurs who form the Diappo Liggueye Cooperative are asking for a loan to support their various businesses. These fall into three categories: fruit juice and ice cream sales, cloth dyeing, and operating a general store selling vegetables, fish and sundries. These diversified businesses will share the loan according to the following budget:

Ice Cream and Juice Sales

Purchase of refrigerator: 200,000 CFA

Stock: 45,000 CFA

Operating expenses: 20,000 CFA

Subtotal: 265,000 CFA

Cloth Dyeing

Dyestuffs: 50,000 CFA

Cloth: 150,000 CFA

Subtotal: 200,000 CFA

General Store

Merchandise: 150,000 CFA

Translated by a Kiva Volunteer.

La commune d’arrondissement de Thiaroye sur mer est une commune où sévit encore la pauvreté. Mais la population très travailleuse lutte chaque jour pour sortir de cette situation. C’est ce contexte de lutte contre la pauvreté que les membres du gie diappo liggueye qui ont pour objectif le progrès socio économique de ses membre en particulier s’est inscrit dans e projet et sollicite vote appui. Les activités tournent globalement autour du commerce .les cinq bénéficiaires sont déjà actives et compte renforcer leurs activités voir les diversifier.. ce prêt sera divisé entre les cinq bénéficiaire . Nous aurons le groupe de Celles qui ferons de la transformation de produits locaux en jus de fruit. Celles qui feront seront dans le commerce de légumes et des produits halieutiques et produit divers .et celles qui seront dans la teinture et la ventes des tissus teints

1ere activité : vente de jus de fruit et de crème glacées : Achat d’un réfrigérateur 200 000 f cfa Produits 45 000 f cfa Fonds de roulement 20 000 f cfa Soit un sous total de 265 000 fcfa 2eme activité : teinture et vente de tissu Matériel de teinture : 50 000 fcfa Consommables (tissu,produit de teinture etc …) : 150 000 fca Soit un sous total de 20 000 fca 3eme activité : vente de légumes , produit halieutique et produit divers Achat marchandises :150 000 fcfa Soit un sous total de 150 000 fcfa

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and stock it with juice and ice cream; to buy fabric and dye; and to stock a general store.

loans.name: Emil

texts.en: M. Emil is 27 years old. He was born in Sumqayıt City of Azerbaijan. Sumqayıt is situated in eastern  Azerbaijan. M. is the only breadwinner for his family. He is dentist, and he began his profession 8 years ago. Emil is a good dentist, and he wants to provide the best service he can to his customers. He is requesting a loan of $500 so he can purchase equipment for the new treatment room. This will enable him to provide more treatments to more people, and also improve the living conditions of his family. He will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for the new treatment room

loans.name: Namig

texts.en: M. Namig is a 42-year-old married father of two children. He is a farmer from Fizuli region and he lives with his family in Sumgayit, situated in eastern Azerbaijan. He started his business in 1993, when he purchased one cow with money he had saved. In 2005, Namig borrowed $500 to add to his own savings of $250 and purchased another milk cow. Since January 2006, prices have doubled. He is requesting a loan of  $1,000 to purchase three small bulls and feed for them. He will repay the loan within 12 months. This will help him improve his stock and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase three small bulls and feed for them

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en: M. Elshan is 45 years old. He was born in Sumqayıt City, which is located in eastern Azerbaijan. He is the father of two children.  M. began his business with $300 in 1996. At first, he sold only children's clothing, but the income wasn't enough for more than his family's basic, subsistance needs. He had difficulty covering expenses for medication, clothes, school etc. He now sells a wider variety of clothes, and is requesting a loan for $700 so he can increase the amount of space he has for his merchandise. The more items he can stock, be better is his income. Expanding his business will improve the living condition of his family. He will repay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Increase the amount of space he has for his business in the central market

loans.name: Arona

texts.fr:
At present, educational needs at kindergarten-level are being very poorly met in the community of Thiaroye-Sur-Mer. Given the extent of the problem, the government does not seem to be in a position to give full support where it is needed in order for this educational sector to flourish. The sector therefore requires initiatives from locally-based associations, which are aware of the need to participate in such undertakings. This is why the Association for the Community Support and Development Initiative of Thiaroye-Sur-Mer – whose aim is to help increase the availability of preschool education and improve its quality – has opened a school within the community that is subsidized by the members of the Association. It is therefore out of concern to achieve these objectives that we are asking you for this loan. The loan will enable us to strengthen the activities in this sector. Students pay a monthly contribution, which will allow us to repay this loan, as well as help with other activities. 
Our Group has 11 members and the reason we have posted only one photo, that of the Association’s president, is because we were unable to have a photo taken of the entire group. We are therefore listing below the names of the other 10 Association members. 
1-Assane Gueye 
2-Lamine Samg 3-Salif Diedhiou 4-Astou K Seye 
5-Chieckh T Diagne 
6-Baytir Sy 
7-Dialma Badji 
8-Massamba Lô 
9-Néné Diabang 
10-Mamadou Dieng
 Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.
Le niveau actuel de couverture des besoins en éducation pour la catégorie classée  dans la petite enfance est très faible dans la commune d’arrondissement de thiaroye sur mer. L’Etat devant l’immensité de la tâche ne semble pas être en mesure de fournir partout où le besoin se fait sentir un cadre adéquat pour l’épanouissement de cette catégorie. Partant de ce fait, le secteur a besoin d’initiatives venant des collectivités de base qui doivent être conscientes de la nécessité de participer à leur prise en charge. C’est pourquoi  initiative de thiaroye sur mer pour la solidarité et le développement (ITSD)_qui ambitionne de participer au relèvement de l’offre d’éducation préscolaire et de participer à l’amélioration de la qualité de l’éducation préscolaire a ouvert une école communautaire qui est subventionnée par les membres de la dite association. C’est donc dans un souci d’atteinte de ses objectifs que venons solliciter ce prêt au près de vous. Ce prêt nous permettra de renforcer les activités dans ce domaine.les eleves font une participation financiere mensuelle qui nous permettra entre autre activité de remboursé ce prêt.

Le GIE ITSD est un groupe de 11 personnes si nous avons affichés une photo ,celle du président du groupement, c'est parceque nous n'avons pas pu avoir la photo de groupe nous vous listons les noms des dix autres membres du groupement.
 
1-Assane Gueye
2-Lamine samg
3-Salif Diedhiou
4-Astou K seye
5-Chieckh T Diagne
6-Baytir Sy
7-Dialma Badji
8-Massamba Lô
9-Néné Diabang
10-Mamadou Dieng

loans.use: To buy educational supplies for a nursery school

loans.name: Subgroup A Of Group Sungura

texts.en:
MOSES, age 49, is married and has 6 kids (ages 21, 19, 16, 12, 9, and 6). He owns a family-run coffee shop where he sells breakfast foods and snacks in the evening. He originally opened this business in 1974. The shop was temporarily closed for 18 years, however, while he served a local government position. It was re-opened in 2000. His business now makes a profit of around $5.50 a day, which he uses to pay house expenses and school fees. He attends to about 40 customers in the morning and 60 in the evening at his shop.

Moses is the leader of Subgroup A of Group Sungura (Swahili for “Rabbit”), which totals 31 members. He will be sharing this loan with subgroup members: Moi M. (tailoring business), Ester J. (sells soft drinks), Agness Z. (food business), and Ibrahimu M. (sells used clothing). Moses knows each of his subgroup members personally since they all live and work near each other. He and his subgroup have taken 3 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to enhance their businesses and were able to pay them back successfully.

Moses used the previous loans on his business and also to purchase a plot of land. With the new loan, he hopes to open a tailoring business for his son.

loans.use: To open a tailoring business for his son.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her business operations

loans.name: Arona

texts.fr:
In Thiaroye-sur-Mer few resources are available for preschool education and state financing is inadequate. Faced with this shortfall, a grassroots initiative called ITSD is under way to provide quality preschool education. Members of the association have formed a preschool and share the expenses related to its operation. They are asking for a loan to support the preschool and plan to repay it out of monthly tuition payments. Please note that in addition to Arona Toure, ten other members belong to ITSD. Their names are listed below.

loans.name: Hernan

texts.es:
Hernan is a farmer, and also raises cows to sell their milk. He lives in the community of Callutaca, in the sector called Laja around 3 1/2 hours from the city of La Paz. Hernan is single, lives with his parents and helps them financially as the oldest son. This loan will be used to buy a good cow, and increase the production of milk. This will be his first loan with Impro, and his evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

Hernan es agricultor y también cría ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche). Vive en la Comunidad de Callutaca sector Laja a tres horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz. El es soltero, vive junto a sus padres a quienes colabora económicamente por ser el hermano mayor. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca lechera de raza mejorada y así incrementar la producción de leche. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO BUY A MILK COW AND HELP GROW HIS BUSINESS
